lines.text: Mr. Owen could only come to the island in one way. It's perfectly clear. Mr. Owen is one of us.
Very stupid to kill the only servant in the house. Now we don't even know where to find the marmalade.
Never in my life have I been accused of any crime, sir - and if that's what you think of me, I shan't serve any dinner.
I know who took the dining room key!
Who?
Rogers! He had the key to the dining room, fact. He unlocks the door, takes a little Indian, goes out and chops up some sticks, fact. And then...
And then he takes the chopper, and splits his own cranium, fact. I'd like to see you do that to yourself, Blore. It would take practice!
Hello puss, looking for a mouse? So are we.
What I'd like to know is if we're the cat, or the mouse?
I'm afraid it's no use watching for the boat. It won't come until Monday.

[staring out to sea]
No boat will ever come, Juliet. We're here forever. What made you love him, Juliet?

[Responding when the others want to give him a key]
Shove it
[pause]
under the door, sir.
So you see, the whole thing has been as inevitable as in a nursery rhyme. When the boat arrives from the mainland, there will be ten dead bodies, and a riddle no one can solve on Indian Island.
Nobody in the general's room, not even the general.
One thing is for certain; he ain't inside so he must be outside.
Brilliant thinking, Blore.
Maybe we've been wrong, built up a nightmare out of imagination.
Two people dead isn't imagination.
If I had a butler like Rogers, I'd soon get rid of him.

[every time he's about to make some blunder]
I get it!
The place for nursery rhymes is in the nursery.
Mr. Owen's hand is plain to see.
Yes, but where the devil is Mr. Owen himself?
